column1: Reading Race, Representation, and Romanticism
This class will meet on alternate Wednesdays at 2pm in the Faculty building, starting on October 18.
This course spans 18th Century and Romantic writing, taking four main avenues to explore: race and representation
column4: women as readers and authors during the Romantic period. These avenues are intended to raise questions current in the literary study of the long 18th Century and early Romantic period more generally. In each case, students will be able to branch out to explore material of particular interest to them for their course-papers, depending on their individual research focus. Main Texts for discussion provide a common basis for each seminar
column5: you need to familiarize yourself with the primary text and any associated reading (*), and bring copies to the seminar. Further Reading is intended for anyone wanting to aspects of the topic in more depth. You will be asked to give short presentations on the texts (two presenters per session) to open the discussion. Running through the seminar is a concern with non-canonical and canonical writing alongside questions involving critical reading itself: on one hand, historical questions to do with the literary marketplace and the canon in the 18 th Century, and on the other, theoretically inflected accounts of texts and reading, including issues of language, materiality, authorship, and gender. The question we will bear in mind is: How far can we engage both historical and critical or theoretical issues?

column1: Main texts for discussion will be available from the DC office. Articles for further reading and a master will be placed on file in the English Faculty Library
column2: please come with your own copies of the main texts. You should start reading Onoonoko now .

column1: Questions about race, gender, and representation in the age of print culture emerge during this period from the margins of the literary canon, signaling an alternative canon in &lsquo
column4: s Oroonoko provides a case-study along with Gallagher&rsquo
column8: . Approaches informed by gender and race can be brought to bear on questions such as literacy, print culture, slavery, empire, and the formation of national identity. Further reading might address fables of cultural contact (Brown), the racial politics of literacy (Aravamudan), and the gendering of the literary marketplace (Gallagher), as well as colonial slavery and literary responses to it.

Class 2: Cultural Capital and the Vernacular Canon

column3: in the literary canon and in relation to the category of the aesthetic sparked a debate about the rise of literary study. John Guillory&rsquo
column4: s work has furthered a variety of accounts linking class, cultural capital, and aesthetic form to the issue of the canon and the rise of the managerial classes. Critiques of Guillory&rsquo
column5: s argument raise questions about value, aesthetics, and the role of economics, as well as issues of canon formation. The question of the elegy, however, also bears on the conventions of mourning and the psychoanalytic or critical understanding of mourning itself, considered as a psychoanalytic and literary category. What kind of act is an elegy and what is the relation between lyric and mourning?

Class 3: Excuses: The Vanishing Typewriter Ribbon

column2: s readings of the major literary and aesthetic texts of the Romantic period continue to inspire both emulation and criticism, as well as being an important example of rhetorical or deconstructive reading in the Romantic period. Derrida&rsquo
column4: s essay on the episode of Marion and the stolen ribbon in Rousseau engages with de Man&rsquo
column5: s concepts of materiality and the machine of writing via a sympathetic yet critical analysis. Derrida probes the elusive confessional aspect of de Man&rsquo
column6: s impersonality, as well as continuing to explore the nature of the textual event via Austin&rsquo
column7: s writing. Rousseau, as the major formative influence on Romantic writing about education, confession, and sentiment, occupies a key place in the deconstructive criticism. But this topic leads to the question of autobiography and confession that are especially crucial to Rousseau&mdash
column8: and to contemporary theorizations of confessional autobiography by Blanchot and Derrida. Can the writing subject ever confess without lie or excuse?

Class 4: The Public and Private Lives of Romantic Books: Women Reading

Reading and authorship become decisively gendered during the 1790s in relation to the feminist concerns and the French Revolution as well as the legacies of 18 th Century sentimentalism and sensibility. Approaches to book-production with a strong economic emphasis provide one perspective on the privatization (or publication) of reading. What community of women readers can be inferred from the fiction of feminist writers such as Mary Hays and Mary Wollstonecraft? How does Rousseau&rsquo
column2: s Nouvelle Eloise inflect the contestatory fictions that struggle with the educational paradigms of Emile (Sophie) and the Nouvelle Eloise (Julie)? Are conceptions of public and private effective in considering &lsquo
column4: novels by women? Studies of the book as cultural commodity exist side by side with accounts of the intellectual and affective formation of the women reader/writer. In what ways did the presence of women in the literary marketplace (as authors and readers) shape the question of the literary as well as the politics of the novel?
